fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By Proposition , the inverse image of the quotient f : D \twoheadrightarrow D/F gives a one-to-one correspondence between prime filters in D/F and prime filters containing F. This way, D/F is local iff \{1\} is prime, in which case F must be prime. The case for maximality follows from the fact that 2 is the only distributive lattice with only one prime filter.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime spectrum of a distributive lattice

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For any distributive lattice D, we use \operatorname {Spec} D to denote the poset of prime filters of D. Equivalently, this is the poset of models of D.

For a distributive lattice D, we define the satisfaction relation as follows: For x\in \operatorname {Spec} D and a\in D, we define x \models a \Leftrightarrow a \in x. In other words, x \models a iff a = 1 in the local algebra D/x.

For any map f : D \to E between distributive lattices:
f is injective iff \operatorname {Spec} E \twoheadrightarrow \operatorname {Spec} D is surjective.
f is surjective iff \operatorname {Spec} E \subseteq \operatorname {Spec} D is a full subposet.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The first statement is an easy consequence of completeness. For the second statement, since \operatorname {Spec} takes regular epis in DL to regular monos in Pos, thus the only if direction holds. For the if direction, take a map f : D \to E, we can factor it as a surjection q : D \twoheadrightarrow E' followed by an injection i : E' \rightarrowtail E. This induces a factorisation on posets q : \operatorname {Spec} E' \to \operatorname {Spec} D, a regular mono, and i : \operatorname {Spec} E \to \operatorname {Spec} E', which is surjective by (1). Hence, if the composite iq is a regular mono, so is i, which implies i is an isomorphism. This way, f must be a quotient.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The Zariski topology on \operatorname {Spec} D is induced by a basis O_p for each p\in D, O_p := \{x\in \operatorname {Spec} D\mid p \in x\}. It is easy to verify that O_1 = \operatorname {Spec} D, \quad O_0 = \emptyset , \quad O_{p \wedge q} = O_p \cap O_q, \quad O_{p \vee q} = O_p \cup O_q, thus this indeed forms a basis.

There is a bijection of frame of opens of \operatorname {Spec} D with the frame \mathrm {Idl}(D) of ideals of D. For any ideal I, the open subset O_I it corresponds to is O_I := \{x\in \operatorname {Spec} D\mid \exists p \in I.\ x \models p\} = \bigcup _{p\in I}O_p.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For simplicity, we construct a dual equivalence between closed sets and ideals of D. By construction, let C_p be the complement of O_p, then the closed set C_I corresponding to I is given by C_I = \overline {O_I} = \bigcap _{p\in I}C_p. On the other hand, given any closed set C we construct an ideal I_C := \{p\in D\mid \forall x\in C.\ x \not \models p\}. Verification is routine.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For a filter F, via Proposition the spectrum \operatorname {Spec} D/F can be naturally seen as a subspace of \operatorname {Spec} D, which is given by \operatorname {Spec} D/F = \{x\in \operatorname {Spec} D\mid \forall a \in F.\ x \models a\} = \bigcap _{a\in F}O_a, This subspace will be upward closed, but in general may fail to be open in \operatorname {Spec} D, since it is an infinite intersection of basic opens. This is the reason why we call quotients of the form D \twoheadrightarrow D/F pro-open, rather than open.

Dually, for an ideal I, let us write the quotient obtained by taking all elements in I to 0 as D \twoheadrightarrow \operatorname {Spec} I/D. By the dual form of Proposition , again we have a natural subspace \operatorname {Spec} I/D \subseteq \operatorname {Spec} D, which can be seen as \operatorname {Spec} I/D = \{x\in \operatorname {Spec} D\mid \forall a \in I.\ x \not \models a\} = \bigcap _{a\in I}C_a = C_I. Thus, \operatorname {Spec} I/D will indeed be closed in \operatorname {Spec} D, hence we refer to quotients of the form I/D as closed quotients. This also implies that a subspace of \operatorname {Spec} D is closed iff it is downward closed.
Under the isomorphism in Proposition , a closed subset C_I of \operatorname {Spec} D corresponding to an ideal I of D is irreducible iff I is a prime ideal.
Suppose C_I is irreducible. If p \wedge q \in I, then C_I \subseteq C_{p \wedge q} = C_p \cup C_q. By irreducibility, either p\in I or q\in I, which implies I is a prime ideal.

On the other hand, suppose I is prime. If C_I is not irreducible, then we can find ideals J,K that C_I \subseteq C_J \cup C_K = C_{J \cap K}, or equivalently J \cap K \subseteq I, and J

Notice that we have a homeomorphism O_p \cong \operatorname {Spec} D/p, where O_p is viewed as an open subspace of \operatorname {Spec} D. Hence, we only need to show \operatorname {Spec} D is compact and sober for all D. Let C_p be the complement of O_p for any p\in D, and suppose we have \bigcap _{i\in I}C_{p_i} = \emptyset . This means that the family \{p_i\}_{i\in I} is inconsistent, thus by compactness, finitely many of them is already inconsistent. Thus \operatorname {Spec} D is compact, and compact opens in \operatorname {Spec} D are all of the form O_p for some p\in D.

To show \operatorname {Spec} D is sober, by Proposition any irreducible closed set C_I corresponds to some prime ideal I. This way, let x\in \operatorname {Spec} D be the complement of I. We now have C_I = \overline {\{x\}}, because x 
ot \in O_p \Leftrightarrow x \in C_p \Leftrightarrow x

Every ascending chain of ideals is stationary.

(1), (3) \Rightarrow (2) is evident: Any ascending chain of elements p_0 \le p_1 \le \cdots induces an ascending chain of principle ideals and a decreasing chain of principle filters. For (2) \Rightarrow (1), suppose otherwise we have a strictly ascending chain of ideals I_0 \subset I_1 \subset \cdots . Then we can choose a strictly ascending chain of elements:
Take p_0 to be an element in I_0.

fr:title.text: Closure properties of Noetherian distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure properties of Noetherian distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Noetherian distributive lattices are closed under finite limits, quotients, and polynomials. The latter means if D is Noetherian, then so is D[x].

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Closure under finite limits and quotients are evident from Lemma . For the polynomial D[x], it is well-known that D[x] \cong D \downarrow D is isomorphic to the order on D, which is thus also Noetherian.

fr:title.text: Noetherian distributive lattices are exactly principle ideal domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Noetherian distributive lattices are exactly principle ideal domains

fr:mainmatter.html:p: D is Noetherian iff every ideal in D is principle.

Suppose D is Noetherian. Let I be an ideal in D. To show I is principle, we define a sequence of elements inductively:
Choose p_0 \in I.
Suppose we have chosen p_0 < \cdots < p_n \in I. If I \neq \downarrow p_n, then we can choose q\in I with q \not \le p_n. This way, take p_{n+1} to be p_n \vee q\in I. It follows that p_n < p_{n+1}. Now since D is Noetherian, the sequence p_0 < p_1 < \cdots must stablise at some point, which implies I = \downarrow p_n for some n. Hence, I is principle.

On the other hand, suppose every ideal in D is principle. If we have an increasing sequence p_0 \le p_1 \le \cdots , then consider the ideal I = \bigcup _{n\in \omega }\downarrow p_n. By construction this is an ideal, thus it is principle I = \downarrow p. By construction, p_n \le p for all n\in \omega . However, p\in \bigcup _{n\in \omega }\downarrow p_n also implies that p \le p_n for some n\in \omega . Thus, the sequence must stablise at some point, and D is Noetherian.

fr:title.text: Prime ideals in Noetherian distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime ideals in Noetherian distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In a Noetherian distributive lattice D, prime ideals are in bijection with meet-irreducible elements, and any element is a finite intersection of them.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We first show every ideal I in D is a finite intersection of prime ideals. Suppose there is a counterexample. Then the set \Sigma of all such ideals are non-empty. By D being Noetherian, \Sigma has a maximal element I. Since I itself cannot be prime, we can find x,y\not \in I with x \wedge y \in I. This way, x \vee I and y \vee I are proper extensions of I with (x \vee I) \cap (y \vee I) = (x \wedge y) \vee I = I. Since I is maximal in \Sigma , both x \vee I and y \vee I has a prime factorisation, which actually implies (x \vee I) \cap (y \vee I) = I also has one, contradictory. Thus, \Sigma must be empty. Now the claim follows from Proposition .

fr:title.text: Prime spectrum of natural numbers under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Prime spectrum of natural numbers under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathbb {N} denote the distributive lattice defined by n \le m \Leftrightarrow m \mid n. In this lattice, we have n \wedge m = \mathrm {lcm}(m,n), \quad n \vee m = \mathrm {gcd}(n,m). Also, the top element is 1, and the bottom element is 0. \mathbb {N} is in fact a Heyting algebra.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \{a_i\}_{i\in I},\{b_i\}_{i\in I} \in D be two finite lists of elements. The finitely presented quotient D \twoheadrightarrow D/\langle a_i,b_i\rangle _{i\in I} induces a subset \operatorname {Spec} D/\langle a_i,b_i\rangle of \operatorname {Spec} D. By definition, for any x\in \operatorname {Spec} D, x \in \operatorname {Spec} D/\langle a_i,b_i\rangle \Leftrightarrow \forall i \in I.\ x \not \models a_i \vee x \models b_i, which means that \operatorname {Spec} D/\langle a_i,b_i\rangle = \bigcap _{i\in I} C_{a_i} \cup O_{b_i}. This way, \operatorname {Spec} D/\langle a_i,b_i\rangle will be constructible in \operatorname {Spec} D.

For a distributive lattice D, the poset of constructible subsets of \operatorname {Spec} D is isomorphic to the Booleanisation of D, i.e. the free Boolean algebra associated to D. In particular, the constructible topology on \operatorname {Spec} D is the Priestley topology.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is because the quotient D \twoheadrightarrow D/\langle a_i,b_i\rangle is surjective, hence any constructible set in D/\langle a_i,b_i\rangle is the intersection of \operatorname {Spec} D/\langle a_i,b_i\rangle with a constructible set in \operatorname {Spec} D. If \mathcal {O}_{D} is a sheaf, then at each prime filter x\in \operatorname {Spec} D, the stalk of \mathcal {O}_{D} at x is given by \mathcal {O}_{D,x} \cong \operatorname {colim}_{p\in x}D/p \cong D/x. As a distributive lattice this is local by Proposition .

fr:title.text: Structural sheaf is a sheaf for Zariski topology

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Structural sheaf is a sheaf for Zariski topology

fr:mainmatter.html:p: \mathcal {O}_{D} is a sheaf of distributive lattices on \operatorname {Spec} D, which is local as an internal distributive lattice.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We verify the sheaf condition. Again since O_p \cong \operatorname {Spec} D/p, we only need to verify the sheaf condition on the total space \operatorname {Spec} D. By compactness, let us consider a finite union \operatorname {Spec} D = \bigcup _{i\le n}O_{p_i} = O_{\bigvee _{i\le n}p_i}, which is equivalent to the fact that \bigvee _{i\le n}p_i = 1. Now suppose we have a compatible family of elements q_i \in D_{p_i} for all i. Compatibility means q_i \wedge p_j = q_j \wedge p_i, for all i,j\le n. This way, we construct the element q := \bigvee _{i\le n} q_i. Firstly, indeed we have q \wedge p_j = \bigvee _{i\le n}q_i \wedge p_j = \bigvee _{i\le n} q_j \wedge p_i = q_j \wedge \bigvee _{i\le n}p_i = q_j. Thus q is indeed an amalgamation of \{q_i\}_{i\le n}. For uniqueness, suppose we have q' with q' \wedge p_i = q_i for all i. Then we have q' = \bigvee _{i\le n} q' \wedge p_i = \bigvee _{i\le n} q \wedge p_i = q. Hence, \mathcal {O}_{D} is a sheaf. It is local as an internal distributive lattice because at each point x\in \operatorname {Spec} D, the stalk by Remark is \mathcal {O}_{D,x} \cong D/x, thus local.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For any distributive lattice D, we use I to denote the open set O_I via Proposition . Then \mathcal {O}_{D}(I) \cong D_I.
A locally distributed space is a pair (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}), where X is a topological space and \mathcal {O}_{X} is a sheaf of local distributive lattice on X.

A morphism f : (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}) \to (Y,\mathcal {O}_{Y}) between locally distributed spaces is a continuous function f : X \to Y, together with a local morphism f^{\sharp } : f^*\mathcal {O}_{Y} \to \mathcal {O}_{X}. Here f^{\sharp } is local iff it is t-conservative. The category of locally distributed spaces will be denoted as \mathbf {Top}_{\mathbb {D}}.

fr:title.text: Spec as a functor to locally distributed spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Spec as a functor to locally distributed spaces

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The functor \operatorname {Spec} : \mathbf {DL}^{\mathrm {op}} \to \mathbf {Spec} given in Theorem can be extended to one \operatorname {Spec} : \mathbf {DL}^{\mathrm {op}} \to \mathbf {Top}_{\mathbb {D}}

On the other hand, we need to show that for any morphism between locally distributed spaces (f,f^{\sharp }) : (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}) \to (\operatorname {Spec} D,\mathcal {O}_{D}), it is determined by f_{\sharp } : D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X}. Fistly, since D\twoheadrightarrow D/p is a localisation, all the morphisms f_{\sharp } : D/p \to _{\sharp } X(f^{-1} p) are already determined by f_{\sharp } : D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X}. Hence, it suffices to show that f is also determined by f_{\sharp } : D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X}. The key of course is the requirement that f^{\sharp } is t-conservative. By the Kripke-Joyal semantics, this means that for any x\in X, the induced map on stalk D/fx \to \mathcal {O}_{X,x} must be t-conservative. This uniquely determines fx since \mathcal {O}_{X,x} by construction is local, and has a unique prime filter. This then determines fx by looking at the preimage D \to \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{X} \to \mathcal {O}_{X,x}.
We will denote the objects of \mathbf {Top}_{\mathbb {D}} that lies in the image of \operatorname {Spec} as affine schemes.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes are determined by topology

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes are determined by topology

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Since \operatorname {Spec} : \mathbf {DL}^{\mathrm {op}} \to \mathbf {Spec} is an equivalence, affine schemes are determined by their underlying topological spaces.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes of free distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes of free distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the free distributive lattice 2[I] over a poset I, recall from Example \operatorname {Spec} 2[I] \cong \mathcal {U}(I). For any x\in \mathcal {U}(I), \mathcal {O}_{2[I],x} \cong 2[I]/x \cong 2[I-x]. Hence, the stalks of \operatorname {Spec} 2[I] are also free.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes of bounded linear distributive lattices

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes of bounded linear distributive lattices

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For a bounded linear order L, recall from Example \operatorname {Spec} L \cong \mathcal {U}_+(L). For any upward closed subset x of L, we have \mathcal {O}_{L,x} \cong \operatorname {colim}_{p\in x}L/p \cong L/x, where L/x is simply the quotient of L by identifying x with 1 and the others remaining the same. In particular, each stalk is again a linear lattice.

fr:title.text: Affine scheme for natural numbers under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine scheme for natural numbers under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the distributive lattice \mathbb {N} given in Example , recall its prime spectral corresponds to prime power p^k, and 0. The corresponding prime filter F_{p^k} is the set of numbers not containing p^k as a factor, and F_0 is the set of positive numbers. This way, we have \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {N},p^k} \cong \mathbb {N} /F_{p^k} \cong \{0 < \cdots < p^{k+2} < p^{k+1} < p^{k} < 1\} \cong \overline {\omega }^{\mathrm {op}}. consisting of the infinite descending sequence of powers of p, and \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {N},0} \cong \mathbb {N} /F_{0} \cong 2. Notice that all the stalks are linear. Since linearity is a geometric condition, it follows that \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {N}} is a linear distributive lattice over \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {N}. However, \mathbb {N} is by no means linear.

fr:title.text: Affine scheme for primes under division

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine scheme for primes under division

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For the sub distributive lattice \mathbb {P} of \mathbb {N} described in Example , its prime spectrum can be identified as primes, plus 0. For any prime p the stalk now kills of all higher powers of p and is simply given by \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P},p} \cong \{0 < p < 1\} \cong 2[x], and we also have \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P},0} \cong 2. \mathcal {O}_{\mathbb {P}} is thus again a linear distributive lattice.
If we glue two affine schemes X,Y together along some standard opens U \subseteq X and V \subseteq Y with U \cong V, then the union X \cup Y is again affine.

A locally distributed space (X,\mathcal {O}_{X}) is a scheme, if for any x\in X there is an open neighbourhood U of x, such that (U,\mathcal {O}_{X}|_U) is an affine scheme. The full subcategory of schemes will be denoted as \mathbf {Sch}_{\mathbb {D}}.
It is well-known that if X is a scheme, then as a topological space it is sober and locally compact. However, it may fail to be quasi-separated or compact.
Let X be a scheme, U an open subset of X. Then (U,\mathcal {O}_{X}|_U) is again a scheme. There is a canonical inclusion U \hookrightarrow X. Morphisms of this form are called open immersion.

The disjoint union X \cong \coprod _{i\in I}X_i of arbitrary schemes is again a scheme. The structural sheaf on an open U is given by \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) \cong \prod _{i\in I}\mathcal {O}_{X_i}(U \cap X_i). They are indeed the coproducts in \mathbf {Sch}_{\mathbb {D}}.

In fact, we can compute the global section of \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+. Under Proposition , it as an open subset corresponds to the maximal ideal M = \mathbb {H}[x]-\{1\}. This way under Proposition , \Gamma \mathcal {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+} \cong \mathbb {H}[x]_M \cong \mathbb {H}[x]. The final isomorphism is an easy exercise. This means the open immersion \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+ \hookrightarrow \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x] induces an isomorphism on global section.

fr:title.text: A scheme is affine iff it is spectral

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A scheme is affine iff it is spectral

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A scheme X is affine iff its underlying topological space is spectral, i.e. iff it is compact and quasi-separated.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let X be a scheme whose underlying topological space is spectral. Let D be the distributive lattice of compact open subsets of X. Let \{U_i\}_{i\in I} be a finite family of affine open covers of X. For any U_i, since U_i is affine, and affine schemes are determined by their underlying topological space (see Remark ), we must have \mathcal {O}_{U_i} \cong D_i where D_i is the principle quotient of D corresponding to the compact open U_i. This way, \mathcal {O}_{X} and \mathcal {O}_{D} agree on this open cover, which implies that \mathcal {O}_{X} \cong \mathcal {O}_{D}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: As a corollary of Theorem , if a scheme X is finite, then it is affine, since finite sober spaces are all spectral.

We say a scheme is quasi-separated if its underlying topological space is quasi-separated. We say it is quasi-compact if its underlying space is compact. The two conditions are often combined together and written as qcqs.

fr:title.text: A quasi-separated but not quasi-compact scheme

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A quasi-separated but not quasi-compact scheme

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Note the scheme \operatorname {Spec}\mathbb {H}[x]_+ from Example is quasi-separated but not quasi-compact.
We say a scheme is irreducible if its underlying topological space is irreducible.

fr:title.text: Irreducible affine schemes have integral global section

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Irreducible affine schemes have integral global section

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For an affine scheme \operatorname {Spec} A, it is irreducible iff A is integral.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Since \operatorname {Spec} D is sober by Theorem , it is irreducible iff it has a generic point, i.e. iff D has a unique maximal filter. This holds iff D is integral by the dual statement of Proposition .

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In fact, the statement can be made stronger.
A scheme X is integral, if it is non-empty, and for every non-empty open U of X, \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) is integral.
If X is an integral scheme, then for any x\in X, the stalk \mathcal {O}_{X,x} will be integral. This is because integral distributive lattices are closed under filtered colimits.

However, the converse is not true though. The simplest counterexample is the affine scheme 2 on the discrete space. It has integral schemes, since both stalks are the initial distributive lattice 2, which are integral. But this affine scheme fails to be integral since its global section is 2 \times 2 \cong \mathbb {B}[x], which is not integral. Hence, being integral is not a local property.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes of integral distributive lattices are integral

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes of integral distributive lattices are integral

fr:mainmatter.html:p: D is integral iff \operatorname {Spec} D is integral.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Suppose D is integral. By Proposition an arbitrary open subset corresponds to an ideal I. Recall from Proposition , the value \mathcal {O}_{D}(O_I) is D_I, the lattice of I-elements of D. Let u,v\in D_I with u \wedge v = 0. This means that for all i\in I, u(i) \wedge v(i) = 0. We show if u(i) \neq 0 for some i\in I, then v = 0. For any j\in I, we have v(j) \wedge u(i) \le j \wedge u(i) = u(i \wedge j). Similarly, v(j) \wedge u(i) \le v(j) \wedge i = v(i\wedge j), which implies that v(j) \wedge u(i) \le u(i \wedge j) \wedge v(i \wedge j) = (u \wedge v)(i \wedge j) = 0. Hence, since D is integral and u(i) \neq 0, we must have v(j) = 0, for all j\in I. This proves D_I is also integral.

fr:title.text: Structural sheaves of integral affine schemes have f-conservative transition maps

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Structural sheaves of integral affine schemes have f-conservative transition maps

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For an integral affine scheme \operatorname {Spec} D, for two non-trivial ideals J \subseteq I, the restriction map (cf. Proposition ) D_I \to D_J is f-conservative.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Since J is non-trivial, pick some j\in J with j\neq 0. Now suppose u|_{O_J} = 0 for some u\in D_I. This way, for any i\in I we have u(i) \wedge j = u(i \wedge j) = 0. By D being integral, it means u(i) = 0, thus u = 0 in D_I.

fr:title.text: A scheme is integral iff it is irreducible

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A scheme is integral iff it is irreducible

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A scheme X is integral iff it is irreducible.

For \Leftarrow , if X is not irreducible, then we can find two non-empty but disjoint opens U,V. This way, \mathcal {O}_{X}(U \cup V) \cong \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) \times \mathcal {O}_{X}(V), which is not integral.

For \Rightarrow , if X is irreducible then so is any affine open, and by Lemma they are all integral. For any open U, to show \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) is integral, we pick a non-empty affine open V\subseteq U. The restriction map \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) \to \mathcal {O}_{X}(V) is f-conservative by Lemma . Suppose we have a\in \mathcal {O}_{X}(U) with a|_V = 0. For any affine open W \subseteq U, we know the image of a|_W in W \cap V is 0, By , a|_W must also be 0. This shows a = 0 in \mathcal {O}_{X}(U).

fr:title.text: Sheaf of ideals generate quasi-closed immersions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sheaf of ideals generate quasi-closed immersions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Now let i : C_{\mathcal {I}} \hookrightarrow X be the closed inclusion. From general topos theory, we know the direct image i_* : \mathrm {Sh}(C_{\mathcal {I}}) \to \mathrm {Sh}(X) is fully faithful, whose essentially image consists of those sheaves \mathcal {F} where \mathcal {F}_x \cong 1 for all x\in \overline {C_{\mathcal {I}}} (see e.g. Construction ). This is in particular true for the quotient sheaf \mathcal {I}/\mathcal {O}_{X}, since for any x\in \overline {C_{\mathcal {I}}}, by Lemma we have (\mathcal {I}/\mathcal {O}_{X})_x \cong \mathcal {I}_x/\mathcal {O}_{X,x} and by definition for any x\in C_{\mathcal {I}}, we know \mathcal {I}_x/\mathcal {O}_{X,x} is the trivial distributive lattice. Hence, there is an essentially unique sheaf of distributive lattices \mathcal {O}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}} where i_*\mathcal {O}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}} \cong \mathcal {I}/\mathcal {O}_{X}.

Furthermore, for any x\in C_{\mathcal {I}}, the map i^*\mathcal {O}_{X} \to \mathcal {O}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}} on stalk over x is given by the quotient \mathcal {O}_{X,x} \twoheadrightarrow \mathcal {I_x}/\mathcal {O}_{X,x} By construction this is a closed quotient of a local distributive lattice where the quotient is non-trivial. Hence, it is a morphism of locally distributed spaces, and we get a quasi-closed immersion C_{\mathcal {I}} \hookrightarrow X

Given Example , we would like a notion of sheaf of ideals, under which the closed subscheme associated to it under Construction will always be a scheme. For this we first consider the case for affine schemes. Our guiding principle is again the bijection in Proposition .

Let I be an ideal of a distributive lattice D. We construct a sheaf of ideal \widetilde {I} on \operatorname {Spec} D as follows: For any a\in D, we define \widetilde {I}(a) := a \wedge I. Evidently, a \wedge I \subseteq D/a is an ideal for all a\in D. This is a sheaf of ideals of \mathcal {O}_{D} by the same proof as proposition .

For a scheme X, we say an ideal \mathcal {I} of \mathcal {O}_{X} is quasi-coherent if for any affine open \operatorname {Spec} A of X, \mathcal {I}|_{\operatorname {Spec} A} = \widetilde {I} for some ideal I of A. We will write the poset of quasi-coherent ideals of X as \mathrm {Idl}_Q(X).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is evident, since the condition exactly expresses that on each affine open \operatorname {Spec} A, \mathcal {I}|_{\operatorname {Spec} A} = \widetilde {\mathcal {I}(\operatorname {Spec} A)}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This way, we first have a generalisation for the results in Proposition .

fr:title.text: Frame of opens of a general scheme

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Frame of opens of a general scheme

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For a scheme X, there is a bijective correspondence between its frame of opens and quasi-coherent ideals \mathrm {Idl}_Q(X) of X.

Again we prove a dual equivalence between \mathrm {Idl}_Q(X) and closed subsets of X. For any (quasi-coherent) ideal \mathcal {I} of \mathcal {O}_{X}, Construction gives us a closed subset C_{\mathcal {I}} already. Now for a closed subset Y of X, we construct an ideal \mathcal {I}_Y such that for any open U of X, \mathcal {I}_Y(U) := \{a\in \mathcal {O}_{X}(U)\mid \forall y \in Y \cap U.\ y \not \models a\}. This ideal is quasi-coherent, because if U is affine open \operatorname {Spec} A, then the intersection Y \cap \operatorname {Spec} A, in the notation of Proposition , is the closed set C_I for some ideal I of A. For any a\in A, \mathcal {I}_{Y}(\operatorname {Spec} A/a) = \{b\in A/a\mid \forall y \in C_I.\ y \not \models b\} = a \wedge I. By Proposition this means \mathcal {I}_Y is quasi-coherent.

Now if we start from a quasi-coherent ideal \mathcal {I}, to show \mathcal {I} = \mathcal {I}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}}, it suffices to show this on an affine open cover. For any affine open \operatorname {Spec} A of X, since C_{\mathcal {I}} \cap \operatorname {Spec} A is closed in \operatorname {Spec} A, it corresponds to C_I for an ideal I of A. Since \mathcal {I} is quasi-coherent, we must have \mathcal {I}(\operatorname {Spec} A) = \widetilde {I}. Hence, \mathcal {I}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}}(\operatorname {Spec} A) = \{a \in A\mid \forall y \in C_{\mathcal {I}} \cap \operatorname {Spec} A.\ y \not \models a\} = I = \mathcal {I}(\operatorname {Spec} A). This shows \mathcal {I}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}} = \mathcal {I}.
At the end, we show that Construction when applied to quasi-coherent ideals of schemes always produces a scheme.

Let X be a scheme and let \mathcal {I} be a quasi-coherent of \mathcal {O}_{X}. Then the closed immersion C_{\mathcal {I}} \hookrightarrow X produced by Construction makes C_{\mathcal {I}} a closed subscheme of X.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The case when X is affine is clear. It is easy to see that when X = \operatorname {Spec} A and \mathcal {I} = \widetilde {I} for some ideal I of A, the closed immersion C_{\mathcal {I}} \hookrightarrow \operatorname {Spec} A is exactly \operatorname {Spec} I/A \hookrightarrow \operatorname {Spec} A induced by A \twoheadrightarrow I/A (cf. Remark ). The case for general schemes is then evident from this.
